nodes.bodyText: suggestion: Feels like this whole method would be better being somewhere outside of LogicalPlanner.
I figured it would be easier to refactor it (cf your comment #5023 (review)) if everything was in one place, but if you want I can split this one out now
This feels wrong - can we now rely on polymorphism here? i,.e. can we not simply call the source nodes and have then do the right thing, rather than having these instanceof conditionals?

What I want to achieve is very specific to nested Join nodes. That means I have three ways I see to solve this:

use instanceof and just flatten the sources here (existing solution)
add a new method getLeafSources (seems like overkill)
change getSources() to recurse (I tried this and it didn't work out of the box, so it requires more changes)

I think the third option makes the most sense, I'll do that in a follow-up PR since it wasn't a one-shot change.

EDIT: getSources() shouldn't recurse because it should give you exactly this node's sources. so it's between adding a new method and keeping it as is. I think I like it as is, but let me know if you feel strongly
Don't feel strongly about it - just feels wrong. Without bringing the code down and trying out your changes I don't know a better way - so happy to merge.
can we not search and replace STT with stream-table-table and II with inner-inner etc?  This would make the test name less cryptic IMHO...
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,782 @@
+{
+  "comments": [
+    "NOTE: these tests only attempt to cover multi-join scenarios; ensuring the validity of the ",
+    "sub-join topologies is delegated to joins.json",
+    "",
+    "The first part of the name is the join sequence - STT, for example, means STREAM-TABLE-TABLE ",
+    "The second part of the name is the type of join - II, for example, means INNER INNER ",
+    "The third part of the name is descriptive of any additional information, if present."
+  ],
+  "tests": [
+    {
+      "name": "STT - II",

nodes.bodyText: Given you have ksql.any.key.name.enabled enabled... why are all your keys named ROWKEY?

nodes.bodyText: Boo: output should not include key columns  in the value :(
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,782 @@
+{
+  "comments": [
+    "NOTE: these tests only attempt to cover multi-join scenarios; ensuring the validity of the ",
+    "sub-join topologies is delegated to joins.json",
+    "",
+    "The first part of the name is the join sequence - STT, for example, means STREAM-TABLE-TABLE ",

+  "tests": [
+    {
+      "name": "STT - II",
+      "statements": [
+        "CREATE STREAM S1 (ROWKEY INT KEY, ID bigint) WITH (kafka_topic='left', value_format='JSON');",
+        "CREATE TABLE T2 (ROWKEY INT PRIMARY KEY, ID bigint) WITH (kafka_topic='right', value_format='JSON');",
+        "CREATE TABLE T3 (ROWKEY INT PRIMARY KEY, ID bigint) WITH (kafka_topic='right2', value_format='JSON');",
+        "CREATE STREAM OUTPUT as SELECT s1.ID, t2.ID, t3.ID FROM S1 JOIN T2 ON S1.ROWKEY = T2.ROWKEY JOIN T3 ON S1.ROWKEY = T3.ROWKEY;"

+      "properties": {
+        "ksql.any.key.name.enabled": true
+      },
